loans.name: Walita

texts.en:
Walita O. is from the city of Tinago, Ozamiz City. She is 55 years old. Walita is married and has 5 adult-aged children.

To make a living, Walita owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling "banana cue" food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling banana snack to the local community. Walita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Walita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Walita is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Walita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 52 years old. She is a resident of Rizal, Santiago City, Isabela. She is engaged in a fruit juice making business called Sweet-O, and it is already registered in the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI). She learned the manufacturing business from training that she attended previously. The business is going well, however, she still needs additional capital to meet the demand of her customers. For this reason, Gloria is asking for the support of Kiva lenders to provide her with a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional capital.

She hopes that her loan request will be granted. Gloria is married to Edgardo and they have three children. The eldest is June - 30 years old; Joy - 28 years old, and Jennifer - 25 years old; all of them are college graduates.

loans.use: working capital for her fruit juice business

loans.name: Reida

texts.en:
Reida is a member of the Embakassy borrower group in Ilala, Iringa. She is 27 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1  child . Her child is 6 years old.

Reida has owned a clothing business selling kanga and vitenge for 7 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.


This is Reida`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 300,000 In order to buy more kanga and vitenge for sale.


With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Reida hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more kanga and vitenge  for  sale

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en:
Leonisa B. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del sur. She is 26 years old. Leonisa is married and has 3 infant-aged children.

To make a living, Leonisa owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a "sari-sari" or general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste etc. in the local community. Leonisa has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Leonisa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Leonisa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Leonisa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley is from the rural community of Bantay Solana, Cagayan. She is 44 years old and married to Alexander, a farmer. They have four children: Erwin, 27 years old; Sheryl, 24; Sherlex, age 19, a college student, and Sheila, 16, a 4th year high school student. The eldest two are already married.

Shirley has been managing her village store for more than 20 years. She and her husband are working hard in order to provide the needs of their family. Her goal in life is to become successful in the business thus, she wants to take out a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP6,000 as additional business capital. She hopes that her request will be granted so she can purchase more groceries that she can sell in her store and have an increase in income and be able to support the education of their children until college.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drugs in bulk

loans.name: Emanuel's Group

texts.en:
B. Emanuel is 57 years old and is the leader of his lending group in Mubende. He is married with eleven children aged between 28 and 14 years and he also cares for three dependents.

Emanuel has been into the sale of clothes in Kabweza trading centre for fifteen years and is able to make 20,000/= a week as profits. He is a friendly and hardworking man and his good customer care has won him many customers. Emanuel has a dream of transforming his shop into a wholesale shop so that he can supply to the other traders as well as to build a family house.

Emanuel needs a loan to be able to buy more clothes of various kinds for resale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Ayodele

texts.en:
Ayodele is 49 years old and married with three children. She sells clothes and shoes which she purchases from Lagos.

Ayodele is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more sarongs, bags and shoes to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Carolyn

texts.en:
Carolyn is a very diligent woman. She has managed a village store for more than five years and she is also engaged in a hog-raising business. She lives in the rural village of Parog-Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is married to Monolito, a company driver in Saudi.

Through her small businesses, Carolyn has been able to help her husband in providing for the immediate needs of their family. With her desire to make her business grow, she is now asking for financial assistance of PHP 20,000 from the lenders. This will enable her to purchase more stock for her store and will also be used for the maintenance of her hog-raising business. She believes that she has the ability to improve her store and make it more productive.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her store and maintain her hog-raising business

loans.name: Pouv

texts.en:
Mr. P., age 47, makes a living driving a taxi-motorcycle, picking up his passengers in and around his community. He currently earns an average of $5 a day and has been running his service for a long time. He is the father of three children, all of whom are teenagers and attend school.

P.’s wife sells soft drinks and gasoline along the street to earn a living. P. would like a loan which will enable his wife to buy more items to sell.

loans.use: To allow his wife to buy more items to sell

loans.name: Lhamsuren

texts.en:
Lhamsuren T. is a widow who has two children aged 13 and 14. Her family lives in a "ger" (nomadic housing tent) district on the plot of land she owns in Arhangay, one of Mongolian central provinces. Both her children are attending a local elementary school.

Since 2004, Lhamsuren has been running a retail business selling dairy products at a small rental stall in the local food market. As a result of her hard work, her working capital has increased from 100,000 tugrugs to 800,000 tugrugs. Her dairy sales income is the only income of her family.

Lhamsuren is an open minded, loyal, and a locally well-respected person. Her dream, is to have her own workplace. With this loan she will purchase more dairy products to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products

loans.name: W Antoinette

texts.fr: T. W Antoinette est née vers 1980 à HOUNSOU dans la commune d’Avrankou et y réside depuis son enfance. Antoinette est mère de deux (02) enfants. Antoinette a comme activité principale la coiffure. Mais en plus, Antoinette vend des mèches, des produits de coiffure et des chaussures. La clientèle d’Antoinette est devenue plus importante et pour ceci, Antoinette a besoin d’avoir le matériel nécessaire pour une meilleure prestation de ses services. C’est pourquoi, Antoinette sollicite l’appui financier d’ALIDé.
texts.en:
T. W. Antoinette was born around 1980 in HOUNSOU, in the community of Avrankou, and has been residing there since childhood.  She is the mother of two children.  Her main work involves hairdressing.  In addition to that, she sells hair extensions, hair care products, and shoes.  Her customers base has become extensive.  For this reason, Antoinette needs the supplies and equipment necessary for offering a better range of services.  This is why she's requesting financial support from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a hair dryer and a sink for washing hair

loans.name: Kivukui

texts.en: Kivukui M. is a 35-year-old married father of three children. He lives with his family in Shanzu, Mombasa, where he uses his motorbike to operate a transport service. He has been in this service for the last five years. His wife Betty is 28 years old and is a businesswoman in Shanzu. Kivukui is borrowing his first loan from KADET and, with the money, he plans to service his motorbike and to open up a café in the same area of Shanzu where most of his clients are. He hopes to own a fleet of motorbikes in future and to also diversify his business by opening a hotel. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To service his motorbike and to start a café

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema  is a member of the Malandege borrower group in Ilala, Iringa, she is 30 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 15 and 10 years old.

Neema has owned a Clothing business selling fabric materials for 8 years, she works 12 hours a day  and she earns a monthly profit approximately 180,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Neema`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 in order to buy more fabric materials for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Neema hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fabric materials for sale

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: Prak S. is the mother of seven children. She currently lives in Siem Reap Province. Since 2000, S. has run a business selling fish in local Psa Kroam Market, and is currently earning an average of $3 per day. As another source of family income comes from her husband who drives a motorcycle. Recently, the income of S.'s husband has slowly decreased due to his no longer working motorcycle. S. has decided to ask for a loan which will allow her to replace her husband's motorcycle.

loans.use: To replace husband's motorcycle

loans.name: Brigitte

texts.fr: V. Brigitte est née en 1984 à Agbomassè, commune d'Avrankou. Brigitte est mariée et est mère de deux (02) enfants.  Brigitte a comme activité principale la coiffure. Mais en plus, Brigitte vend des mèches et des produits de beauté. C’est pour augmenter le stock de ses produits que Brigitte sollicite l’appui financier d’ALIDé.
texts.en:
V. Brigitte was born in 1984 in Agbomassè, in the community of Avrankou. She is married and the mother of two children. Her main work involves hairdressing. But in addition to that, Brigitte sells hair extensions and beauty products. To increase her stock of products, she's requesting financial support from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products and hair extensions to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Life Group

texts.en: Agnes is 54 years old and is a married mother of four children. Currently all of her children are working except her youngest, who is in school. She is a trader who deals with assorted products like aluminum cooking utensils, plastic buckets, bowls, and lunch boxes. She mostly sells through hawking, or house to house selling, and has been trading for a year now.  She has attracted lots of customers who purchase from her. She treks to Kumasi to purchase her stock of goods and has recently been facing challenges to buy stock as a result of inadequate funds. She requests a loan amount to buy more supplies like cooking utensils and rubber buckets, which are in frequent demand by her numerous customers. With the loan she believes she will be able to make more profit to build a store and reduce the time walking on the street to sell goods. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more supply of the products like cooking utensils, rubber buckets etc.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is 38 years old and married. She lives in Benin City, Nigeria. She is a fashion designer and also sells sarongs and tailoring materials. She has been in this business for an extremely long time. Eunice is requesting a loan to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Vann S., 55, is a low-income person living in Siem Reap Province. She is a good and determined single mother who tries to feed her seven children. She has three married children who live separately, while her four remaining children are staying in the family home, while holding a variety of jobs. Vann S. sells fresh fish in the market to earn a living. Every day in the late morning, Vann S. goes to a fishermen's market to buy fish in bulk. Then she hurries to bring the fish to the market, where they sells them. Vann S. will be using her first loan to buy a motor for family's transportation purposes.  Any remaining money will be used to purchase fresh fish to sell.

loans.use: To Buy a Motor for Transportation

loans.name: Teo's Group

texts.en: N. Teo is the leader of her lending group in Mubende. She is 35 years old, the single mother of 4 children, and she cares for 3 dependants. Teo is a farmer and does most of her work in Kyanasiki village where she has a farm. Here, she grows Matooke, sweet potatoes and cassava. Her profits pay for her children’s school fees and general well-being. She wants tp buy her own lorry from which she can be able to transport her goods to the big markets at a reasonable cost. Teo needs a loan to help pay her children’s school fees and will use part of her profits to repay back her loan.

loans.use: To pay school fees for all of her children

loans.name: Yèyinou Béatrice

texts.fr: Z. Yèyinou Béatrice est née en 1972 à HOUNVE, commune d'Adjarra. Béatrice est mariée et mère de trois enfants dont deux scolarisés. Béatrice  vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille grâce aux revenus de son activité. Pour arriver à mieux aider son mari, Béatrice veut mieux développer son activité. Pour y arriver, Béatrice compte équiper son salon de couture de matériel nécessaire. Alors, Béatrice sollicite l’appui financier d’ALIDé pour y arriver.
texts.en:
Z. Yèyinou Béatrice was born in 1972 in HOUNVE, in the community of Adjarra.  She is married and the mother of three children, of whom two are in school.  Béatrice comes to her husband's aid in meeting family expenses, thanks to the revenues from her business.  To be able to help her husband further, she wants to improve her business.  To do so, she plans to equip her dressmaking salon with the necessary supplies and equipment.  Béatrice is therefore requesting the financial support of ALIDé to achieve this.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and sewing supplies

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en: Rosana C. is from the village of Saray, Iligan City. She is 51 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Rosana owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rosana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Truthful Group

texts.en:
Rose, the leader of this group, is divorced with four children who are currently in school. She is a 40 year-old trader. Rose believes in hard work and dedication as the primary antidote to minimizing poverty and for that matter she is very serious about her business. She trades in foods such as plantain. She wants to use the loan to buy a larger supply of plantains in order to better serve her customers throughout the season especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in the country. She believes that with the loan she will be able to buy plantains directly from the farmers avoiding middlemen who retail to her at a high price.

Rose is the leader of a trust bank group called "Truthful" and is the one sitting in the group photograph. The members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and farmers. In this group, the members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To bulk buy plantains

loans.name: Senior

texts.en:
Senior, as she is called, is 52 years-old and married with six children. All her children are in school in the community development school. Senior is a petty trader and sells items such as cooking oil, yams, plantains, spices, pepper, onions, smoked and dried fish, tinned tomatoes and bags of rice. These products sell very fast and she easily recovers her capital in order to buy new stock. Senior takes delivery of goods from the capital city of Kumasi.

With her six years experience in her business she now wants to add other food items which are frequently demanded by her customers such as maize and eggs. She believes that this can be possible with the help of this loan and she plans to use the loan to buy bags of raw materials. She is also convinced that the loan will help increase her stock in the event of a price hike.

loans.use: To buy food

loans.name: Monday

texts.en: Monday lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria and sells motorcycle spare parts. He is asking for a loan of NGN 50,000 in order to purchase more motorcycle parts to sell. He is 34 years-old, unmarried and has no children.  He thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle spare parts

loans.name: Raphaela

texts.en:
Raphaela is a member of the Frelimo borrower group in Ilala, Iringa. She is 32 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 18,  and 13 years old.

Raphaela has owned a shop business  for 8 years, she works 14 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Raphaela`s second loan from BRAC-Tanzania, she requested the amount of 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more shop commodities for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Raphaela hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her shop

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a 24-year-old married man with two children, one of whom is in school. He works very hard and saves for the future. He enjoys selling and is motivated to work hard because he dreams of a better future for his children.

Patrick owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items such as rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed milk powder, etc. However, he is constrained in making meaningful progress by low capital. He is requesting a loan to buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc. to make increased profits. Patrick believes that, with his good customer relations, the loan will enable him to realize his dream.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc.

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en:
Rolando N. is from the village of Saray, Iligan City. He is 44 years old and single. To make a living, Rolando owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling rice in the local community. Rolando has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rolando joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rolando is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Joseph Kahato

texts.en:
Joseph is 52 years old and married with six children. He specializes in charcoal buying and resale. He lives with his family in Dagoretti, Nairobi, which is also where his charcoal business is based. He has been in the business for about one year and his profit has been rising steadily in this period.

Joseph does not have a previous credit history with any other MFI and was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend. This will be his first loan. He wants to use the money to buy charcoal to add to his current stock. In the futture Joseph hopes to have a bigger charcoal wholesale store.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of microentrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. You can obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more charcoal stock for resale

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a 30-year-old married mother of three children. She lives with her children and husband on the outskirts of their town. Currently, her children are in primary and basic level school respectively. As a mother, Gladys works very hard to support her husband, a farmer, in taking care of the family.

For the past two years Gladys has been a local manufacturer of soap. She combines ingredients such as palm oil, soda powder, cocoa pods and coconut oil, to obtain her soaps. She is not able to produce soap in large quantities due to lack of funds. Gladys wants to take advantage of a loan to buy more raw materials and processing equipment to scale up production. She hopes to improve her income to support her children's education. It is her desire to provide her children with a good quality education, and she believes that will make her dream come true.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients such as palm oil, soda powder, cocoa pods, coconut oil, etc.

loans.name: Ngoay

texts.en: Mr. S., 30, has a skill in carving statues that he learned from his grandfather. He carves pieces of wood into statues and sells them to people who want to decorate or adorn their home. Mr. S. is married to Mrs. Srey, age 23, who is a homemaker. She takes care of her five school-aged children. Mr. S. is requesting a Kiva loan to increase his business capital. This will assist him in making more profit and gaining valued customers.

loans.use: To increase his business capital

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie S. is from the village of Lugait in Misamis Oriental province. She is 57 years old, married and has four adult children. For over three years Elsie has owned and run a sari-sari (variety) shop where she sells both food and other daily necessities to her local community. She earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009 Elsie joined HSPFI to gain access to their financial services. This will be her first loan from them. She is requesting 5000 PHP to be used to expand and vary her line of products and so generate additional revenue.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy new items to expand and vary her shop's offerings

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is 57 years old and is married with seven children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria, where she sells engine oil.

Janet hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell. She has been in this business for a long time. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell

loans.name: Twelve Apostles Group

texts.en:
Felicia is 33 years old and is married with three kids who are all in school. She lives with her family in a small village in the Western Region of Ghana.

Felicia owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood. She is a very skillful and talented hairdresser and has been in business for seven years now. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service. Therefore, she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons (hair extensions), pomade, shampoo, activators, etc., to serve her customers.

Felicia is the leader of a trust bank group called “Twelve Apostles”. She is the one seated in the group photograph. Most of the members of these groups are petty traders, food vendors and farmers, etc.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of hair products for her salon

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a member of the M. borrower group in Ilala, She is 46 year old woman, she is widowed and a mother of 5 children. Her children are 29, 25, 18, 15, and 10 years old.

Maria has owned a food business selling chicken with potatoes for 12 years. She works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 180, 000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Maria`s second loan from  BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more potatoes and chicken for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Maria hopes to save more money an expand her business.

loans.use: To by more potatoes and chicken

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina is 29 years-old and married with three children in school. She lives with her family in a small village in the western region of Ghana.  For the last 15 years, Faustina has owned and operated a beauty salon in her neighborhood. She is a skilled and talented hair dresser who believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service. Therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products such as weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators etc. in order to better serve her customers. She purchases her supplies from Kumasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

loans.use: To buy hair products

loans.name: Medad's Group

texts.en:
(The person in the small photo is M. Medad and he was interviewed, and in the photo, Charles N. was missing at the time of photo taking)

M. Medad is the leader of this lending group in Mubende. He is 28 years-old and married with four children aged between two and twelve years. He is a business man involved in the sale of alcohol from his bar as well as his home. Before opening the bar three years ago through the help of a loan, Medad made and sold alcohol from his home. His bar is located in Kazinga and generates approximately 80,000/= profits a week enabling him to look after his family and pay the children’s school fees. He has a dream of increasing his capital base by accumulating sufficient savings to enable him to have a decent life. Medad is asking for a loan to purchase a greater variety of alcohol for resale.

loans.use: To buy alcohol

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is 35 years-old and married with three children. Two of the children are already in school and the youngest is still breastfeeding.  Joyce says that life is a bit of a challenge but she tries hard to overcome challenges through the help of God. She sells earrings and necklaces made with silver, copper, and gold brands in the market. She purchases goods from Kumasi and resells to her customers. She would like a loan in order to purchase earrings and to upgrade her stock. She wants to help her husband save more for the children's education and use profits to further grow the business.

loans.use: To buy assorted earrings and necklaces in bulk.

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing is 40 years old and divorced with two children. She sells foodstuffs like plantain, cocoa yam and garri (roasted cassava) in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.

Blessing hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Nai

texts.en:
Nai N. sells a few wares in front of her home. She sells items like soft drinks, sweets (candies) for kids, and some cooking supplies. To meet her family’s living expenses, her husband works as a room preparer for a hotel and gets a specific salary. This couple has three school-aged children.

Recently, part of Nai N.’s inventory has been exhausted; she wants to resupply and is requesting a loan to accumulate more inventory to continue selling.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Edward's Group

texts.en:
R. Edward is the leader of his lending group in Mubende. He is 64 years old and married with ten children aged between 23 years and 8 months. He also cares for three dependents.

Edward is a farmer and has been farming for forty-five years now. He transports his own produce to the markets and is only able to make profits of 30,000/= (approx. $15) a week and this is mostly due to the frequent seasonal changes and the high transport costs since he uses public means to transport his goods. He is happy that in most times, his goods have been of good quality hence earning him much. He spends most of his money on school fees and medical care since he would like to educate his young children to university level.

Edward needs a loan to be able to purchase produce for resale in order to increase his earnings since the past season was not favorable to him. He is such a hardworking man.

loans.use: To buy more produce to expand his business

loans.name: Rose Wairimu

texts.en: Rose Wairimu N. is 47 years old and is married to Edwin Muraya who is a businessman. They have two children, Peter and Josephine, who are 21 and 17 years old respectively. Rose has been in the clothes-selling business for four years. She did not have a previous credit history until she was introduced to KADET by friends who interact with her as she operates her business. Her business is located in a densely populated area where her customers live. Rose has applied for a loan which she plans to use to expand her business. Rose believes she is hardworking, determined, and focused. Her future dreams are acquiring a clothes stock from foreign countries and to start an exhibition in the central business centre in Nairobi. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Omoruyi

texts.en:
Omoruyi is married with six children and she is 40 years old. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria where she sells local pots. She has been in this business for a long time.

Omoruyi hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase more local pots to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more local pots to sell

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is 38 years old and married with two children. She sells provisions like noodles, toothpaste, cornflakes, sugar, etc.

Dorothy hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She expresses her gratitude to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Amos Ng'ang'a

texts.en: Amos is 32 years old and married with one child. He is a retailer of cakes and bread and his business is situated in Kikuyu town where his customers live. He has been running the business for nine years and it has generated a steady income. Amos has never borrowed from another micro-loan financial institution. This will be his third loan from KADET and he plans to use the loan to increase his stock of cakes and bread. Amos hopes to own his bakery in the future. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase his stock of cakes and bread

loans.name: Cossi Célestine

texts.fr: C. Cossi Célestine est née vers 1971 à Aguégué. Célestine est mariée à GBEZEN Joseph. Le couple a cinq personnes à charge tous scolarisés dont quatre leurs propres enfants. C’est Célestine et son mari qui supportent ensemble les charges de la famille. La famille vit à PIN depuis dix ans. C’est le bois de chauffage que vend Célestine. Mais en plus, Célestine vend de poissons et des divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.) ; tout ceci chez elle à domicile. Célestine a déjà cinq ans d’expérience dans ses activités. Célestine a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits d’ALIDé ; crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a su faire évoluer ses activités.
texts.en:
C. Cossi Célestine was born around 1971 in Aguégué.  She is married to GBEZEN Joseph.  The couple provide for five people, all in school, of whom four are their own children.  She and her husband support the entire family.  They all have been living in PIN for ten years.  Célestine sells fish and a variety of items: candy, cookies, canned foods (milk, sardines, tomatoes), sugar, pasta, soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath, batteries, candles, etc. -- all out of her home.  She already has five years of experience in her work. Célestine obtained two ALIDé loans in the past and repaid them.  She knew how to use them to develop her business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods, some firewood, and boxes of fish

loans.name: Ashrafdjon

texts.en: Ashrafdjon is 32 years old and he is the father of two children. His wife is a housekeeper and she supports him in everything he does. The most important thing to him is that his children in future enter university and successfully finish it, so that they will have a better tomorrow and become professionals. Ashrafdjon is a hardworking person and he has been providing taxi services for more than nine years. He wishes to keep his taxi business growing and for this he needs to have his vehicle in good working order. He needs to buy spare parts to improve its condition and that is why he is requesting a loan. Thanks to this work, Ashrafdjon has been able to stabilize his family’s quality of life. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for repairing his vehicle

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience is thirty-nine years old and married with two children. She lives with her family in a rented apartment in the city. Her first born has completed senior high school while the last child is in junior high school.

Patience sells products like beans, soya beans, groundnuts (peanuts), rice, millet, maize, etc. and has been in business for twelve years. She buys her cereals and other goods from villages and supplies to the market women in her communities. Patience says that food vendors also come to her to buy in large quantities.

Patience is requesting a loan to top up her working capital to enable her to buy stock in bulk on each trip to meet the demands of her customers. Being able to buy in bulk is very advantageous. It means fewer trips to fill the demand, and it is a hedge against the rapidly rising prices. She therefore wants the loan for this purpose.

loans.use: To purchase cereals in bulk

loans.name: Peter Njoroge

texts.en: Peter is 58 years old married with three children. He grows vegetables and supplies milk to clients who come from within the Kiambaa location. He also sells his vegetables in Nairobi city. He earns a monthly profit of approximately kshs 29,000. Peter has never borrowed from another micro-finance institution. This will be his third loan from KADET and he will use it to buy a water pump so that his vegetables get enough water for growth. Peter hopes to own a big dairy farm and to buy more land to produce more vegetables for his supply. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy an electic water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.en:
K. Gulchehra has been selling groceries and beverages for more than 5 years. A true entrepreneur, she studies the market to determine client needs and preferences. Industrious and enterprising, Gulchehra is focused on expanding her business. Presently, she has a monthly income of about $100-$150. She is currently seeking a loan of $600 USD, which will help her to increase her assortment of fresh merchandise and expand her business. With the increased sales and profits, Gulchehra hopes to expand her grocery business and improve her family’s living standards.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history. It was the site of a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after it gained its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise and expand her business

loans.name: Béthanie Plus Group

texts.fr:
Mbasa L. 40 ans, est président de la Banque Communautaire dénommée « Béthanie Plus » composée de 36 membres, située à Kisangani dans la province Orientale, au nord-est de la ligne de l’Equateur en République Démocratique du Congo. Cette province est frontalière au nord avec le Soudan et avec l’Ouganda au nord-est. Elle a été victime de plusieurs guerres, surtout celle de 2000 an dont deux armées étrangères se sont affrontées dans la ville causant ainsi beaucoup de dégâts et pertes en vies humaines.
Aujourd’hui, la vie économique reprend progressivement dans la ville, surtout avec le concours des micro-entrepreneurs dont Mbasa L. fait partie. Il a commencé son activité en 1982. Il en a acquit une expérience solide et est demeuré client fidèle qui a obtenu 6 fois les prêts de l’IMF HOPE RDC et les a remboursés correctement. Le prochain crédit lui permettra de renforcer le stock de sa marchandise en achetant d’autres sacs à revendre en vue d’accroitre le revenu. Son affaire lui procure hebdomadairement un bénéfice de $90. L’objectif de Mbasa et son épouse, est de faire étudier leurs 10 enfants qui sont âgés entre 4 mois et 20 ans dont 8 seulement vont à l’école. Mbasa est déterminé à développer son activité avec l’appui financier de Kiva à travers ces prêts.
texts.en:
Mbasa L., aged 40, chairs the Community Bank "Béthanie Plus" made up of 36 members and located in Kisangani in the Eastern Province, north-east of the equator in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.The province borders in the north Sudan and in the north-east Uganda. It was the scene of several wars, mainly the war in 2000 when two foreign armies confronted each other in the city and caused thus a lot of destruction and loss of human lives. Currently the economy of the city is gradually recovering, notably thanks to small business owners such as Mbasa L..

Mbasa began his activity in 1982 and has acquired a solid experience. He is a regular client of Microfinance Institution HOPE DRC; he received six loans and repaid them on schedule. His next loan will enable him to buy more sacks for resale and increase his income. He earns a profit of $90 a week from this activity. The goal of Mbasa and his wife is to enable their children to study. They have ten children aged from 4 months to 20 years and only eight of them attend school. Mbasa is determined to develop his business with the financial help of Kiva loans.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock up by buying and selling more sacks

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Bakhtiniso

texts.en:
Bakhtiniso has 9 years of experience as a seamstress. She first worked with her mother, which is how she learned her trade. Four years ago she started her own business, and with the help of some money her husband saved, she was able to buy the sewing machine she needed to open her business. Bakhtiniso specializes in national women’s dresses. Her workshop is in her home and she works Monday through Sunday from 8:00am until 7:00pm. She would like to take out a loan of 4000 Somoni to be able to purchase a new modern sewing machine for her business. Bakhtiniso is counting on your help and thanks all of you.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history. It was the site of a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after it gained its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Léontine

texts.fr: K. Léontine est née vers 1973 à PIN. Léontine est mariée à AGBEZOUNNOU Pierre.  Léontine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés mais, seulement trois sont encore à sa charge. Léontine vit avec ses enfants dans le troisième arrondissement de Porto-Novo. Léontine a fait le cours primaire mais depuis quinze ans Léontine est dans la restauration. Léontine vend les pâtes de maïs, de causette d’igname et de manioc, du riz, etc. C’est Léontine seule qui supporte les charges de ses enfants.
texts.en:
K. Léontine was born around 1973 in PIN.  She is married to AGBEZOUNNOU Pierre and is the mother of four children who are all in school, but only three of them are still in her care.  She lives with her children in the 3rd District of Porto-Novo.  Léontine has completed primary school. And since she was 15 years old, she has been in food service.  She sells pâtes de maïs (different kinds of polenta), yam and cassava chips, rice, etc.  She is the only one supporting her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn, cassava flour, yam chips, and sauce condiments

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca, divorced with five children, all currently in school, lives with her family in a rented apartment in Accra. She started her fish sales business five years ago. Traveling to fishing communities to procure her high quality assortment of fish, she prepares and serves them to her many customers. Fish-selling is the main source of income for her family. .

Rebecca is requesting a loan to enable her to buy cartons of fish in bulk to meet the demand of her customers. Buying in bulk means that she will make fewer trips to fill demand and have some protection against the rapidly rising prices. She believes her capacity to improve her business will enable her to sponsor her children's education through university.

loans.use: To purchase assorted fish in bulk.

loans.name: Muhaiyo

texts.en:
A. Muhaiyo is 41 years old. She is married with two children. With the purpose to help her husband in supporting the family, Muhaiyo is running her own business. She is selling jewelry. Muhaiyo has been in this business for more than 16 years. Initially she started with the working capital in the amount of $1,000 US. Currently the turnover capital increased.

Today Muhaiyo requests $2,700 US to purchase new items of jewelry like earrings, rings, bracelets, and chains in order to enlarge the range of goods for selling. This is the eleventh loan for Muhaiyo and she promises to observe all the procedures concerning the payment of the loan as she used to do with previous loans. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new items of jewelry to enlarge the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Married with five kids who are currently in school, Victoria is forty-seven years old. She sells foodstuff like cassava, plantain, maize etc. in the local market of her community. Selling for the past twenty years, she has lots of experience to win customers. She treks to farming communities to buy her foodstuff from the hands of local farmers which saves her from middlemen who inflate the prices. Victoria is an achiever and her focus is to save enough to provide her kids with a quality education for their future careers. 

She requests a loan to top up her working capital to enable her to buy stock in bulk each trip to meet the demand of her customers. Being able to buy in bulk is very advantageous. It means fewer trips to fill the demand and it is a hedge against the rapidly rising prices. She therefore wants the loan for this purpose.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuff in bulk.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en: Sonia has a restaurant where she sells drinks and pepper soup to her customers. She has lots of customers coming to her restaurant. She hopes to retain her customers. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 31 years old and married with 2 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Oiniso

texts.en:
Their education is the most important inheritance Oiniso and her husband can give to their four dear children. They are both very responsible parents and they work very hard in agriculture and farming so that they can give their children the opportunity to finish school, an opportunity they never had due to poor finances.

This happy mother has been working in agriculture since getting married and with the unconditional help of her husband and elder son, she buys and sells cattle in order to cover the family’s most urgent needs. Even so, she now finds herself with more expenditures and she would like a loan in order to increase their capital by increasing their number of cattle. Oiniso and her family are waiting for your quick response. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle

loans.name: Zakaria Muiruri

texts.en:
Muiruri is a single man aged 25 years. He owns a retail shop at Nderi shopping centre and his customers are from the same location. He started the business two years ago.

He noticed that he needed to restock his shop and thus he enquired around and joined KADET. With no previous history of borrowing from another MFI, he applied for his first loan which he repaid well and on time. This will be his second loan and he plans to use it to restock his retail shop.

His hopes to own a wholesale business in future.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: adding stock to his retail shop

loans.name: Oghogho

texts.en: Oghogho is 32 years old and married with 2 children.  She is a friendly and hard-working woman. She sells sarongs of various colors and sizes. This business is her source of income. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris is 37 years old and she is married with two children. She owns a retail shop at Rironi shopping center where she serves her many customers. She has been running the business for a period of about nine years with a monthly profit of approximately kshs 25,000.

Damaris was introduced by a friend who is also a member of KADET and this will be her first time to borrow from an MFI. She intends to add to her current stock with the loan applied for.

In future Damaris hopes to own a wholesale store in Kikuyu town.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Adding stock for retail shop

loans.name: Gulmira

texts.en:
Gulmira has always been a very hard-working woman. She used to work sewing and selling national dresses for women and girls. Starting the business wasn't easy because she didn't have the necessary machine to do the work. However, with the help of her mother, she was able to collect enough money to buy her own machine four years ago and has been working in embroidery ever since. Gulmira would like to grow her business even more by purchasing a modern automated embroidery machine. With your help she can achieve her goal.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase an automated embroidery machine.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth, who lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria, is a 40-year-old married mother of six children.  A seller of drinks and provisions, Elizabeth hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia, a 38-year-old married mother of two children, both currently attending school, loves selling, the business through which she makes a living. A trader in herbal medicine, Lydia treks to villages to purchase the prepared local herbs, creams and medicines that she retails to her customers. These herbs and local medicines treat common diseases including malaria, typhoid, diarrhea, cholera, boils, etc. The medicines are prepared under strict hygienic conditions supervised by the Food and Drugs Board, and many people use them because of their effectiveness in treating the aforementioned diseases.

Lack of adequate working capital prevents Lydia from carrying enough stock to make profits sufficient to support her family. She is therefore requesting a loan to increase her stock in order to scale up sales. She believes the loan will enable her to save more income to support her children in school.

loans.use: To purchase local herbs and medicine.

loans.name: Nadine

texts.fr: A. Nadine est née vers 1981 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique de la République du BENIN. Nadine est mariée à BOKOSSA Hervé, un enseignant. Nadine et son mari ont deux enfants tous scolarisés. Nadine et sa famille vivent à Houivié depuis huit ans. C’est le mari de Nadine qui supporte les charges de la famille. C’est les friperies et le gasoil que  Nadine venddepuis environ sept ans. Nadine achète ses articles à Missèbo à Cotonou, Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin et les vend à Djassin. Nadine a déjà eu deux d’ALIDé pour faire évoluer son activité. Nadine a bien remboursé ces crédits et elle sollicite un autre aujourd’hui pour mieux développer son activité.
texts.en:
A. Nadine was born around 1981 in  Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of the Republic of Benin.  She is married to BOKOSSA Hervé, a teacher. Nadine and her husband have two children who are both in school  She and her family have been living in Houivié for eight years.  She and her husband are the ones supporting the family.  Nadine has been selling second-hand clothing and diesel fuel for about seven years.  She purchases her goods in Missèbo in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin.  She sells them in Djassin.  She has already had two ALIDé loans for advancing her business.  She repaid these loans and is today requesting another one to develop her business further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothing and diesel fuel

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith, 30, sells women's clothes of various sizes and colors.  This married mother of three children hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more women's clothes to sell

loans.name: Goodluck

texts.en: Goodluck, 40 years old and married, produces palm oil in wholesale and retail to his customers. In this business for many years,  Goodluck hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more palm fruits to process into palm oil to sell. Palm oil is essential in Nigeria because it is used in the preparation of Nigerian soups such as okro, egusi, etc. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase palm fruits to process into palm oil to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a member of the Bwawani borrower group in Ilala, Iringa. She is 43 year old woman.she is married and a mother of 5 children. Her  children are 23, 21, 19, 17,  and 9 years old.

Victoria has owned a clothing business for 5 years, she works 6 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 180,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Victoria`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more used clothes for sale.

With the additional profits she gains from the use of this loan,Victoria hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for sale

loans.name: Felechina

texts.en:
Felechina is a member of the Dodoma borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 40 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 5 children. Her children are 29, 25, 20, 17, 10 years old. She also cares for other 1 dependent.

Felechina has owned a Business selling local beer for 3 years, she works 4hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Felechina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for making local beer.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Felichina hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more  maize

loans.name: Eliane

texts.fr: B. Eliane est née en 1975 à Porto-Novo. Eliane est mariée à HOUNGBEDJI Hervé. Eliane est mère de quatre  enfants mais en plus, elle et son mari ont trois autres enfants à charge. Ensemble avec son mari, Eliane supporte les charges de la famille. Eliane a fait le cours primaire et vend actuellement de tissus, chaussures et sacs de sortie. Eliane achète ses articles à Cotonou,  Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin et les vend à Adjinan à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique de la République du BENIN. Eliane a déjà eu deux crédits d’ALIDé pour faire évoluer son activité. Eliane a bien remboursé ces crédits et elle sollicite un autre aujourd’hui pour mieux développer son activité.
texts.en:
B. Eliane is born in 1975 in Porto-Novo. Eliane is married to HOUNGBEDJI Herve. She is the mother of four children and in addition, she and the husband have three other children to take care of. Together with the husband, Eliane supports with family expenses. Eliane has primary education and currently sells cloth( fabric), shoes and bags for outing. She buys her items in Cotonou, the economic capaital of the Republic of Benin and sells them in Adjinan in Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of the Republic of Benin. Eliane already had two loans from ALIDE in order to transform her business. She repaid correctly her loans and is requesting another one today to develop better her business.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cloth (fabric) and ready-to-wear outfits

loans.name: Maimua

texts.en:
Maimuna is a member of the Lami borrower group in Ilala, Iringa, she is 38 year old woman she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 22, 19, 15 years old. 

Maimuna has owned a  charcoal business for 10 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 180,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Maimuna`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Maimauna hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To  buymore charcoal for sale

loans.name: Florah's Group

texts.en:
Florah K. is the leader of her lending group in Ntungamo. Forty years old and married with five children ranging in age from 22 – 12 years, she also takes care of three dependents. For the past seven years she has been both a pineapple dealer in the Kafunjo trading centre and a retail shop operator. She is able to make weekly profits of 30,000 UBX although her pineapple business is faced with fluctuating prices and substantial transportation costs.

A friendly lady who would like to expand her business by acquiring a storage facility for her pineapples and educate her children to be able to fend for themselves, Florah is requesting a loan to restock her retail shop as well as buy more pineapples for resale.

loans.use: Buying more pineapples and restocking her retail shop.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Matha is a member of the Sokoni borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 26 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 6 and 2 years old.

Martha has owned a clothing business for 6 years, she works 9 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 50,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Martha`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh i order to buy more vitenge and kanga(fabric) for sale.

With the additional profits she gains from the use of this loan, Martha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more kanga  and vitenge for sale

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph Gitau has been making furniture for the last 20 years in Naivasha town. He is a 54 year old man who is married to Hannah Wanjiku. Together they have three children in school. Having no previous credit history from any other microfinance institution, he was introduced to KADET by a friend who is already a client. This will be Joseph’s first loan from KADET, which he will use to buy materials and tools to expand his workshop. His future aspiration is to open a chain of workshops in Naivasha town.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To buy materials and tools to expand his workshop

loans.name: Phoebe's Group

texts.en: K. Phoebe, 47, is a hardworking and determined lady with a retail shop business in Itojo Trading Centre. She has been running her shop for 23 years and her biggest challenge is thieves that disturb her shop at night, however much she puts in good security measures. She is a married lady with four children between the ages of 12 and 20, and she takes care of two dependants. She is able to make 15,000/= daily as profit, and she will need to expand her shop to be able to educate her children. Phoebe needs a loan to restock her shop with more goods to avoid shortages.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop with more goods

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith is 35 years old and married with three children. She sells shoes to take care of her family's needs. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more shoes to sell, to make more profit for her family's upkeep. Faith says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is a member of the Kichangani borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 29 year old woman, she is widowed and a mother of 4 children. Her children are 23, 20, 17, 9 years old.

Martha has owned a business selling local beer for 15 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 180,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Martha`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities for local beer.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Martha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for local beer

loans.name: Nabiha

texts.en: Nabiha is a 40-year-old mother of five, living with her husband and children. She has been working from home as a chef on demand for the past four years. Today, Nabiha is requesting to borrow $600 to purchase items that would help to improve her business and generate more profit.

loans.use: To purchase items

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes P. is a 43-year-old married mother of four children. She is married to Johnstone P. who is a businessman in Shanzu. The family lives in Shanzu which is in the coastal town of Mombasa. Agnes earns her living through grocery sales in Mikoroshoni, and she also sells fish and clothes as side businesses in the same area. She started with the grocery store then expanded to selling fish and clothes within a period of four years.

Agnes is accessing her first loan from KADET and she plans to purchase more grocery stock, fish and clothes to sell. She is very hardworking and industrious and she hopes to expand into a general merchandise store to fully maximize her income. She also plans to acquire a motorbike for passenger services.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To purchase grocery stock, fish and clothes

loans.name: Steven's Group

texts.en:
J. Steven is a 29-year-old farmer conducting his businesses from Mubende trading centre. When he first got funding, he grew food for home consumption and changed to growing food for sale. It has been three years since he made the transformation. He is able to make 60,000/= as weekly profit and he wishes to increase this by having more plantations and being able to buy from other farmers whenever he does not have enough for sale.

At the moment, he has started the construction of his own house and he is working hard to ensure that it is complete, with a storage room for his produce. He is married with three children between the ages of 4 and 9, and he takes care of two dependents. Steven needs a loan to help him buy produce (e.g. maize, since it’s the planting season) for himself and to sell to others.

Steven is the leader of his lending group in Mubende.

loans.use: To buy maize for planting and for sale

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter W. is a 36-year-old man, married to Serah Wambui, and together they have two children ages 5 and 7 years old.For the last three years, Peter has been baking and supplying cakes within Naivasha town, using a motorbike for transport. He joined KADET through a friend, and this will be his first loan. He proposes to expand his business by buying more stock for his small bakery. This will enable him to meet the high demand and reach more clients; hence, improving his family's living standards. His future plans are to convert his small bakery into a big company, able to bake bread and cakes for major events.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: Expansion of his cake business

loans.name: Zipporah

texts.en:
Zipporah T. is 35 years old and a married mother with two children. Her husband, Patrick, is a prison warden. Zipporah runs a retail shop in Shanzu where she sells different household items and foodstuff. She has been in the business for one year. She learned about KADET through a friend and she is now accessing her first loan. She plans to stock more foodstuff and to do some minor renovations to her shop.

In the future, Zipporah hopes to own a bigger, well stocked store. She also hopes to start selling her goods wholesale.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuff and do some renovations to her shop

loans.name: Precious

texts.en: Precious sells bags, shoes and sarongs to make money to support her family. She is 30 years old and married with a child. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 nairas to purchase bags, shoes and sarongs to sell. Precious says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags, shoes and  sarongs to sell

loans.name: Beware About Us Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel G. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'Beware About Us'. He is 27 years old and an elementary school drop-out due to the civil crisis. Emmanuel is also single and has no child but wants to catch up with life. He lives and does business in the Bassa community area, which is close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

This community is known as very old settlement where people leave the Grand Bassa county (a county in southern Liberia) to settle because people of that community speak the same dialect they speak; it is also known as a community where people fight poverty to change their lives.

Money exchange, charging mobile phones batteries, and selling GSM recharge credits to the residents of Bassa community is Emmanuel’s business. He has been doing this business for 2 years and started with LD$6000.00 and is still moving forward.

Emmanuel always keeps his business environment clean and tidy; that’s why his customers continue coming back to do business with him and that makes business go forward.

Emmanuel needs this loan to buy more mobile phone chargers, GSM recharge cards wholesale, and to increase the cash he uses to exchange currencies in order to improve his business. Emmanuel wants to reach a higher level in business and dreams of changing his life to a better one where he can help others.

loans.use: to buy more mobile phone chargers, GSM recharge cards wholesale, etc.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter K. is 23 years old and married to Scolar Wambui.They have two children both under the age of two. He has been employed as a motorcyclist, offering taxi services within and around Naivasha for the last year.

Peter got to know about KADET through one of his group members and was happy to join. This being his first loan, Peter plans to add to his savings and buy his own motorbike. This will enable him to increase his income hence improve his living standard.

In future Peter hopes to own his own cab and offer taxi services in and beyond Naivasha.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Purchasing a motorbike
