loans.use: Purchasing new goods to expand inventory

loans.name: Tamemsu Group

texts.en:
This is Abdul M. K., Mabinty C., Kadiatu J. and Adama T.. They named their group Tamensu, a Temne phrase meaning “Give us a try”. They are small scale businesspeople in Waterloo small town, about twenty-two miles from Freetown. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. Each of them is requesting a loan of Le 500,000.00. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses. 

Abdul M. K. (right) is the leader of this group. Abdul is fifty years of age. He was born in Masorie village, about thirteen miles from Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone.  He is married with six children. Five of his children are attending secondary and primary schools, the last is not of school going age. Abdul owns a pharmacy in Waterloo. He has been selling medicines for the five years now. Before now, he was working for an N.G.O.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Antoney Group

texts.en:
Here is Rugiatu K. and Zainab B.. They named their group Antoney.  They are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. This is not their first loan from Kiva through SMT. They had all previously received several loans from Kiva through SMT. Each one of them in the group received a loan of Le 800,000 during the last loan cycle. That loan created meaningful impacts in the lives of these borrowers. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees.  They’re also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans.  Today, they are requesting a loan of Le 1,000,000 each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Rugiatu K. (left) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-five years of age. She was born in a small town called Robuya Romende, in northern Sierra Leone. She now resides in Makeni with her husband and three children. Her husband is also a businessman and two of her children are attending school and the other is not of school going age. Rugiatu sells slippers, she has been a businesswoman for fifteen years now.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Loveth

texts.en: Loveth is 42 years old and she is married with 5 children. She sells tubers of yams to make a living in Sapele, Delta state, Nigeria. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more tubers of yams to sell.She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yams to sell

loans.name: We Dee Woman Group

texts.en:
This is Marie K., Aminata D. and Serrah K.. They named their group We Dee Woman.  They are local entrepreneurs in Waterloo, twenty miles from Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are getting from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. They are requesting a loan of Le 500,000 for each. This loan can significantly impact the lives of these people. They will be able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees.  They will also be able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loan. 

Marie K. (right) is the leader of the group. Marie is forty-two years of age and was born in Waterloo. She is married to a businessman and they have four children. Their first child is in college, the other has just sat to the West Africa Senior Secondary Schools Examinations, and the others are in Junior Secondary School I and II. Marie sells market food since a child. With this loan, she will be able to add more goods into her stall.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Wusum Women Group

texts.en:
This is Maseray K. and Tenneh S.. They named their group Wusum Women. These entrepreneurs have received several loans from Kiva through SMT.  The previous loans have had meaningful impacts in the lives of these entrepreneurs. The last loan they received from Kiva through SMT was for Le 800,000.00 each. Now, they are requesting a loan of Le 1,900,000.00 to enable them further strengthen their businesses.

Maseray K. (left) is the leader of this group. Maseray is fifty-five years of age. She was born in a village called Makari, about five miles from Makeni. She is married to a lorry driver and the two of them have four children. Two of Maseray’s children are now grown-ups and two are in Junior Secondary Schools. Maseray has been a businesswoman for ten years now, she sells fire woods. 

With this loan of Le 1,000,000.00, Maseray will use it to buy one truck load of fire-wood. A truck load of fire-wood cost Le 600,000 including transportation. So far, Maseray faces no major challenge in her business. Business is going on fine for her and she enjoys doing it. 

With the profit she makes, Maseray will use part of it to repay her loan, pay her children’s school fees and meet her daily financial challenges.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en:
Z. Parviz is 28 years old. He is married but has no children yet. Parviz is a jack of all trades in the sphere of construction and repair. He is working as a foreman in the team providing the services on minor and major repair of the houses and apartments. At the same time he is a very good carpenter. Parviz is dreaming to have many children and to build the house for each of them. Knowing all this Parviz is working really hard in order to make the business successful and generating the stable incomes for his large family. Now he is planning to purchase the construction equipment. Being loaned for the first time Parviz promises to work harder thus to be able to repay the loan in time.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.use: Purchasing of the construction equipment.

loans.name: After You Na Me Group

texts.en:
This group of entrepreneurs called their group After You Na Me. Each owns a small stall at the Magburaka town market selling different sorts of market food. They have benefited from previous SMT/Kiva loans. With the help of previous loans, their businesses improved in size and quality, they can thus better look after themselves and children. However, having fully repaid their last loan successfully, they are again seeking a new one to further strengthen their businesses. They are thus seeking a loan of Le 3,000,000 to enable them develop their businesses.

Marie C. (second from left) is the leader of the group. Marie is thirty-seven years of age, she was born in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a businessman and they have two children together who are in Junior Secondary School II. Marie sells market food since childhood days. With this loan, she will be able to buy gallons of palm-oil.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is 31 years old and she is married with 2 children.She is a friendly and hard working woman.She sells shoes and bags.She hopes for the loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more shoes and bags to sell.She is indeed grateful to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Bath Morie United Group

texts.en:
AL-Hassan S. B., on the left, is the leader of this group. AL-Hassan sells used clothes and has been in the business for three years now. AL-Hassan will top-up the loan to get himself a bale of secondhand clothes. He is approximately age 55, married, with five children. Two of AL-Hassan’s children are already married, two are young and one is in secondary school. He was born in Matokoka village which is about five miles from Magburaka town.

These are members of the Bath Morie United group. They are petty traders in Magburaka town, in Northern Sierra Leone. For the first time, these people are seeking a loan in order to boost their businesses. With a loan of Le 500,000 each, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses so that sales and profit will improve. Consequently, they will be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: Business investment

loans.name: God Help We Group

texts.en:
This is Makuta T., Matenneh C. and Kadiatu K.. They are businesswomen in Waterloo small-town, twenty miles from Freetown city. They named their group God Help We. This will be the first loan these women are receiving from SMT, a Partner of Shine on Sierra Leone. With this loan, these women will be able to add more goods to their businesses make better profit and consequently improving their standard of living.

Makuta T. (middle) is the leader of the group. Makuta was born in Kabala town, in northern Sierra Leone. She is now approximately fifty years of age. She is married to a motor-driver and the two have four children together. Three of her children are now married and is in class one. Makuta sells cigarettes, matches, milk, coco, sardine, butter, chewing gums, mints etc.  She has been a businesswoman since childhood days palm-oil, the most popular cooking oil in wholesale. She has been a businesswoman since childhood days.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
This is Zainab F., Jariatu B., Isatu K. and Isatu M.. They called their group Believe In God II. This is the first loan they are receiving from SMT/Kiva. They’re requesting a loan of Le 500,000 for each to enable them expand  their businesses. This will helped them a lot. They will able to make a lot of profit from the loan, thus be able to solve many of their problems. 

Zainab B. (left) is the leader of this group. Zainab was born in a village called Rotufunk. She is twenty-six years of age, married to a businessman and they have three children. One of her children is in class five, the other is in class three and the last is still not of school going age. Zainab sells fire-woods and charcoals. She has been in this business for over ten years now. With this loan, she will be able to buy 200 – 300 bags of charcoals and forty – fifty piles of fire-woods.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Tamaraneh Ii Group

texts.en:
Isha F. (left) is the leader of this group. Isha has been a businesswoman for seven years now, and she sells bowls, dishes, spoons, sheaves, funnels, etc. She is married to a nurse and they have seven children. Some of their children are in secondary schools and the others are in primary schools. Isha is approximately 28 years of age. She was born in the small town of Mile Ninety-one, in Northern Sierra Leone.

Isha F., Adama K. and Yeabu S. are members of the Tamaraneh Group. Tamaraneh is Temne meaning “Let’s help each other”. They are local entrepreneurs in Waterloo small town – 20 miles from Freetown. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. They are requesting a loan of Le 500,000 each, to enable them to improve their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses both in terms of size and quality. Consequently they can make better profits and improve on their standard of living.

loans.use: Business investment

loans.name: God Gee Group

texts.en:
This is Hawa C., Mohamed K. and Memunatu K.. They named their group God Gee.  They are small scale entrepreneurs who want a loan of Le 1,500,000 to enable them improve their businesses. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs will be accessing from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, sales will thus improve and so also will be their sales-to-profit-margin. With a larger profit at their disposal, they will be able to better look after themselves and children.  

Hawa C. (right) is the leader of this group. Hawa was born in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. She is now age twenty-five, married to a driver and they have one child who is just two years of age. Hawa sells market food – pepper, palm-oil, etc. at Makeni second largest market. Hawa has now had three years of experience in business.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Loko Masama Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Loko Group. They are Mamsusu K., Mamusu B. B. and Marie S.. They are all residence of Waterloo small town, twenty-two miles from Freetown. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. These entrepreneurs sell different type of goods but their businesses have been developing at a very low pace due to the lack of capital. With SMT opening a new branch in Waterloo in partner with Shine on Sierra Leone, they have come to solicit a loan of Le 1,500,000 in order to help improve their businesses and living standards

Mamusu K. (left) is the leader of this group. She is approximately age thirty-six, born in Loko Massama, Port Loko district, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a building contractor and they still have no children. Mamusu sells cotton and has been in this business for more than ten years now.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan is 37 years old and married with two children. She sells clothes like laces, sarongs, etc. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Sam Try Group

texts.en:
Hawa B. (left) is the leader of this group. Hawa owns a kiosk where she sells provisions such as cans of milk, sugar, mayonnaise, cheese, butter, breads, etc. She also sells market foods like palm oil – the country’s most popular cooking oil. Hawa has been a businesswoman for six years now. Hawa lives in Makeni together with her husband and two children. Hawa’s husband works for two of the leading mobile networks in the country as a sales agent. Her twin children are attending primary school and are in class II. Hawa was born in Mabolo, in the Kambia district of Northern Sierra Leone about 28 years ago.

This loan is for members of the Sam Try group. They are small scale entrepreneurs in Makeni city, in Northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a first-time loan of Le 1,500,000 from SMT/Kiva, in order to help themselves improve their businesses and living conditions.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Yoni Group

texts.en:
Here are Namina B. and Wara K.. They named their group Yoni group, named after their home village of Yoni Boma, in the Tonkolili district, northern Sierra Leone. These entrepreneurs are seeking a loan of Le 1,300,000 to enable them increase the size and quality of their businesses. 

The leader of this group is Namina B. on the left. Namina is now age forty, married to a police officer and the two of them have five children, between the ages of eight and twenty-two. Manina sells market food – rice, palm-oil (the favorite cooking oil), “margi” (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper etc. She has been in this business for fifteen years now. With this loan, she will be able to expand her business, makes more sales and better profit, and consequently improving on her living standard.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Ahmadiyya Primary School, Six Mile Group

texts.en:
These are teachers from a primary school in Six Mile village, about 26 miles from Freetown. They have come to SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone, to seek a loan in order to meet their immediate financial needs. Because teachers’ salaries are usually small, many of them find alternative means of making a living. Some engage in businesses and in agriculture, while others organize extra classes for the pupils (though this is a practice the government is trying to abolish). 

These teachers seek a loan in order to embark on meaningful projects, such buying of a plot of land, starting/completing the building of a house, paying school fees for either their children or for themselves to pursue further studies, buying furniture, etc. Gradually, out of their monthly salaries, they will repay their SMT/Kiva loan.

Andrew (third from right) is a senior teacher at the school and head of this group. He is 43. He was born in Yoni small town, in northern Sierra Leone. He married a businesswoman and they have six children – two in secondary schools and two in primary schools. Mr. K. has been teaching for 19 years. He will use part of the loan to pay school fees for his children, as schools are reopening pretty soon. He will also use part of the loan to repair his house and buy food for the family.

loans.use: Pay school fees for his children and repair family home

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 32 years old and married with three children. She sells sarongs of various colors. She hopes for the loan amount of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 63 years old and she is married with 8 children. She sells fire woods in retail to her customers.She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more fire woods to sell.She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewoods to sell

loans.name: House Wives Group

texts.en:
Here are Isatu C., Alimany K., Sama J., Sallamatu B. S. and Mabinty A. C.. These are small scale entrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of Le 500,000.00 for each to enable them add more goods into their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and better profit. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing and in their academic pursuit. 

Isatu C. who is second from left is the leader of this group. She is thirty years of age, born in Koya, about seven miles from Freetown. She is currently residing in Makeni, together with her husband and four children. Her children are attending schools, the youngest being in class one and the eldest in class six. Isatu has been a businesswoman since childhood days and she is currently selling slippers and bars of soap. With this loan, she will buy soap-making materials like palm-oil and caustic soda. She will also buy a carton of slippers.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Malaneh Group

texts.en:
The Malaneh group is a group of small-scale businesswomen in Magburaka town, which is in northern Sierra Leone.

The leader of the group is Yeabu S., pictured on the left. Yeabu was born in Magburaka town about fifty-five years ago. She is a widow with eight children. Seven are now on their own and one is in Senior Secondary School III.

Yeabu sells market food such as onions, pepper, oil, tomatoes, and “margi.” She has been selling food at the market for more than forty years now.

Through Kiva’s partner, Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), the members of the Maleneh group are seeking a Kiva loan of 500,000 Leone (SLL) each. With these loans, they will be able to expand their businesses, make better profits, and consequently improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To invest in their small-scale woman-owned businesses.

loans.name: Women's Wing Group

texts.en:
The Women’s Wing group is a group of small-scale businesswomen in Makeni city, which is in northern Sierra Leone.

The leader of the group is Mabinty G., pictured on the right. Mabinty was born in Makili village in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a teacher and they have four children. Two of Mabinty’s children are in secondary schools and two are in primary schools.

Mabinty has a restaurant where she sells cooked rice, meat, and vegetables. She also has a small box at the corner of her restaurant where she sells cigarettes, mints, matches, biscuits, lollipops, etc. Mabinty has been a businesswoman for more than five years now. With this loan, she will be able to expand her business.

The Women’s Wing group is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 Leone (SLL) in order to improve their businesses. With such a loan, they would be able to add more goods, increase sales, and make better profits. Consequently, they could better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing, and educating them.

loans.use: To invest in their woman-owned businesses.

loans.name: Ganiatou

texts.fr: O. Ganiatou est née vers 1946. Ganiatou est mariée à YESSOUFOU Mouftaou. Ganiatou est mère de quatre  enfants. La famille vit à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. C’est le mari de Ganiatou qui supporte les charges de la famille ; ce qui permet à Ganiatou d’utiliser les revenus de son activité pour développer celle-ci. C’est les divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.) que Ganiatou vend dans sa boutique construite à côté de sa maison. Ganiatou achète ses articles à Datokpa, grand marché International du Bénin. Ganiatou a besoin de plus de moyens financiers qu’elle n’en possède pour mieux développer son activité et pour diversifier celle-ci à la vente de sacs de charbon de bois. C’est la raison pour laquelle Ganiatou demande de crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Ganiatou O. was born around 1946. Ganiatou is married to Mouftaou Yessoufou. Ganiatou is the mother of four children. The family lives in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Bénin. It is Ganiatou's husband who takes care of the family's expenses; This allows Ganiatou to use the income from her business to develop it. Ganiatou sells various items (candies, cookies, cans of milk, sardines and tomatoes, sugar, pasta, laundry, dish and bath soap, batteries, candles, etc.) in her store that is built next to her house. Ganiatou purchases her products in Datokpa, the large, international market of Bénin. Ganiatou needs more financial resources than she possesses to further develop her business and to diversify it by selling sacks of wood coal. It is for this reason that Ganiatou is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various products and sacks of wood coal.

loans.name: Easter Group

texts.en:
These are small scale businesswomen in the northern city of Makeni. They have come to SMT for the very first time to seek a loan of Le 500,000 for each to enable them expand their businesses. With a loan of Le 500,000, they will be able to add more stocks into their businesses, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school, feed and clothe them. 

Kadiatu C. (right) is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni, thirty-two years ago. She is married to a businessman and they have two children. One of his children is in class III and the other is still not of school going age.  Kadiatu sells slippers and dishes. She has been in this business since childhood days. Kadiatu will invest Le 200,000 of this loan into her slippers business and the remainder she will use to buy more dishes.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Honest Group Ii

texts.en:
This is Aminata K., Adama K. and Fatmata K.. They call their group Honest Group II. They are small scale businesspeople based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improving on their standard of living. 

Aminata K. (right) is the leader of this group. Aminata was born in Makeni. She is now age twenty-four, married to a businessman and they have two children; between the ages of two and four. Aminata sells palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) and rice. She has got eight years of experience in business. With these loan, she expects to buy eight – ten barters of palm-oil (five gallons make a barter). Currently, a barter of palm-oils is sold at Le 50,000 – 60,000.00.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Nuriddin

texts.en:
J. Nuriddin was born in 1965 and is married with three children. As an aspiring and hard-working man he has always dreamed of achieving success in whatever he does. Thus, when he joined IMON International last year, he was able to make much progress with his previous loan, which he invested mostly in crop farming. Then, he saw a new business opportunity: rearing of the young cattle, which is very profitable because of the constant demand for meat at the market. Given this loan, Nuriddin will purchase young cattle and feeding for them to expand his business. He plans to use the profits from his business to educate his children, improve the structure of his home, and improve the standard of living of his family.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing the cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 42 years old and married with 4 children. She sells provisions like milk,soap,etc. she hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Savrioy

texts.en:
N. Savrioy is a widow and mother of one son. She has been running her own business for five years. Savrioy sells clothes and shoes for teenagers in a store that is located in a densely populated part of the city. She is very nice and polite and has many clients. The business is quite stable and serves as a significant source of income for the family.

Savrioy has been a client of IMON for three years and has managed to pay all her loans accurately and precisely. She now requests $1,100 dollars (USD) in order to purchase some new inventory of goods.

Savrioy deeply appreciates your support and sincerely thanks all of you.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is known for its rich history. It was a key post along the Silk Road and was once ruled by Alexander the Great. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC, and communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new inventory in order to increase the range of resale goods.

loans.name: Jackilne

texts.en:
Jackline is a member of the Kichangani borrower group in Kihesa, Iringa. She is 32 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 19, 11, 7 years old.

Jackilne has owned a clothing business for 1 year, she works 5 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 30,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Jackline`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tanzanian shillings in order to buy more kanga and vitenge (fabric) for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Jackline hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more kanga  and vitenge for sale

loans.name: Mananeh Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Mananeh Group, who are all businesswomen in the Tonkolili district headquarter town of Magburaka. They are applying for a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean leone each from Kiva lenders through SMT. This will be the first loan this group is accessing from SMT/Kiva. 

With the help of this loan, they will be able to improve their businesses, make more sales and increase profits. Consequently, these women will be able to improve their standard of living – they can look after their children better and be able to meet most of their domestic needs.

Kadiatu K. (on the left) is the leader of this group. Kadiatu was born in Magburaka town about 45 years ago. She is married to a businessman and the two of them have three children. Two of their children are in Junior Secondary School I (JSS I), and the eldest is doing some farming for a living. Kadiatu has been a businesswoman for seven years. She sells market food like rice, pepper, “margi,” onions, oil, etc.

loans.use: Invest in theri businesses

loans.name: Wan Word Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale business entrepreneurs in the small town of Waterloo, about 22 miles from Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone. Business has been growing at a very slow pace for these entrepreneurs because of low capital. With the opening of an SMT branch office in partner with Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo; these women formed a group in order to solicit a loan. With a loan, their businesses will improve, they will make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living.

These entrepreneurs named their group Wan Word. Isha F. (left) is the leader of the group. Isha is now 44 years of age. She was born in Port Loko district, northern Sierra Leone. She now lives with her husband and four children in Waterloo. Her husband is a lorry driver and her four children are attending primary and secondary schools. Isha sells charcoal and fire woods. She has been in this business for nine years now.  With this loan, Isha expects to buy something like 100 – 200 bags of charcoal and 3,500 piles of firewood in villages near Waterloo.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Memunatu K.

texts.en:
This is Memunatu K. D., age forty-two. Memunatu was born in Freetown. She currently resides in Waterloo where she is married and runs her business. Her husband is a monthly wage earner. They have two children – one in Junior Secondary School III and the other in class II.  Memunatu is a dealer in cosmetics and boutique stocks – she sells clothes, trinkets, shoes, bags, body beauty creams etc. She has been in business for over twenty years now. This will be her very first loan from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. She is requesting a loan of Le 4,000,000 to help her strengthen her business.

With this loan she receives from SMT/Kiva, Memunatu is expecting a vast improvement in her business and increased profit. The increased profit will be reinvested into the business, some will be saved for future use and the remainder will be used to support her husband in providing food for their household and paying school fees and other school related charges for the children and meeting other daily financial challenges.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
R. Jamila is 44 years old. She and her husband-cook have three children of school age. Already for 17 years she is selling the clothing and footwear for kids. The income from the business Jamila is spending for educating of her children as she and her husband are dreaming that their children will have the higher education. Jamila has been provided with the loans by IMON almost for 3 years. For the entire period of time she has shown herself as an accurate client. Today she requests $800 US for purchasing new goods for selling. Jamila promises to pay the loan in time and thanks all supporting her.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: Purchasing of new goods for selling in order to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 65 years old and married with 8 children.She sells tubers of yam in retail to her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more tubers of yam to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yams to sell

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy is 50 years old and married with 5 children. She sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. She hopes for the loan amount of N50000 to purchase refrigerator to cool her drinks. She thanks you for the support.

loans.use: To purchase more refrigerator

loans.name: Atagbeh Town Group

texts.en:
This is Mamusu C., Foday K. K. and Sorie M.. They named their group Atagbeh Town. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. Each of them is requesting a loan of Le 500,000.00. With this loan, they will be able to increase the sizes and qualities of their businesses and consequently make better profit and improve their standards of living. 

Mamusu (left) is the leader of this group. Mamusu is 37 years of age. She was born in Yele village, in Tonkolili district, northern Sierra Leone. She is married with six children, who are attending primary and secondary schools.  Marie sells Yoruba items (these include a variety of assorted little stuffs first introduced and sold here by the Yorubas from Nigeria. The few I can name in English include spoons, rings, bracelets, “madoni”, etc). Mamusu has been a businesswoman since childhood days. With this loan, she will travel to neighboring Guinea to buy “madoni” (a sort of cream with medicinal value) at a cheaper rate and sells in Waterloo.

loans.use: Purchase madoni for resale

loans.name: Djurakul

texts.en:
S. Djurakul is a 63-year-old farmer, who believes that he is the richest man in the world considering that he has 5 adult children. Djurakul has two milk cows and sells dairy products to the local and capital traders. He has 7 years of experience in raising cattle and selling dairy products. The milk products are in very high demand in his village. Djurakul’s orders for these products are very high but the milk his cows give is not enough for traders and he decided to apply for $1200 USD to purchase an additional cow and fodder. Djurakul is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to improve his living with this loan.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: Purchasing the cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Mugomeh Group

texts.en:
This is A. M., Yankuba A. and Ismail C.. They call their group Mugomeh, a Mende phrase meaning “Let’s meet together”. This will be their first loan from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. They are requesting a loan of Le 1,400,000 to enable them boost their businesses.

A. M. (right) is the leader of this group. A. is thirty-four years of age. He was born in a village called Shengeh, Moyamba district, southern Sierra Leone. He is married with three children – one is in class one and the other is not of school going age. A. sells used shoes and has been doing business for fifteen years now.

loans.use: To invest in his business

loans.name: Test We Group

texts.en:
This is Angela S., Mbalu K., Mariatu K., Mohamed K. M. and Abass K. S.. They named their group Test We. They are all local entrepreneurs in Waterloo small town, twenty miles from Freetown. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. Each of them is requesting a loan of Le 500,000.00. With this loan, they will be able to increase the sizes and qualities of their businesses and consequently make better profit and improve on their standards of living.

Angela (right) is the leader of this group. She is thirty-seven years of age and was born in a small town called Batt K. in northern Sierra Leone. She is married with four children who are attending school. Angela sells cooked rice, meat, vegetables and cold soft drinks and has been a businesswoman for over sixteen years now. With this loan, she will buy a cool-man, two bags of rice, ten gallons of palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) and other cooking ingredients.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Nematillo

texts.en:
U. Nematillo has raised cattle and farmed for 19 years. With two children and the responsibility of providing food for his home has been able to improve his family’s financial situation thanks to the excellent care that he has given his animals. Today Nematillo finds himself in need of purchasing calves to raise in order to be able to take greatest advantage of raising and selling them when necessary. For this reason Nematillo is obtaining loan from IMON International in order to obtain these animals and raise them so that in time they can be used to support his family.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: Purchasing of young cattle and construction materials for improving his cattle-shed

loans.name: Trust And Pay Group

texts.en:
This is Wurie Bella B. and Kadiatu S. of the Trust and Pay group. They are petty-traders in Magburaka town, northern Sierra Leone. For the third time, they are seeking a loan of Le 1,800,000 from SMT/Kiva to help them further improve their businesses and standard of living. With the help of previous SMT/Kiva loans, these entrepreneurs have experienced a vast improvement in their businesses and personal lives. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are again seeking a new loan from Kiva lenders through SMT.

Wurie Bella B. (left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Magburaka town about twenty-eight years ago. She is married to a businessman and they have five children together. Two of her children are now in Junior Secondary School III (JSS III), one is class one, the other in class five and the last is not of school going age. Wurie sells market food. She has been in this business for four years now.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Mallaya Group

texts.en:
Mallaya is a group of 5 borrowers led by Anthony F..  He is 30 years old and married with 2 children aged 5 and 2 years, who are in kindergarten and 1st grade. Anthony happens to be a 3rd grade dropout because he had to take care of his parents who were both old and illiterate, so he decided to stand and take care of them. He lives and sells in West Point, close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia.  It is known to be a very rough environment where every child seeks for themselves. 

Anthony’s business is selling house finishing materials like locks, nails, hinges, etc. He has been running this business for 3 years in order to take care of his children and his parents also.  Anthony started this business with LD $3,000 which he borrowed from his brother and was later paid.

He always talks to his customers in a good manner, gives them a better price in order to maintain them, and doesn't give credit to his customers because he believes giving credit drives customers away. These are his little secrets.

Anthony needs this loan to purchase more goods like locks, hinges, nails, etc. in order  to increase the business size.  In the future, Anthony wants to own a store in and around Monrovia.  Anthony dreams of establishing a business for his family that will help and take care of their needs. He also has a plan to build a house for him and his family to relocate from West Point.

loans.use: To purchase more goods like locks, hinges, nails, etc. to increase the business size.

loans.name: Go Ahead Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Go Ahead group. Members of the Go Ahead group are small scale businesspeople in the town of Magburaka in the Tonkolili district. They are seeking a loan from SMT/Kiva for the first time. Each is requesting a loan of Le 500,000 to improve his or her business and consequently improving his or her standard of living.

Mohamed T. (on the left) is the leader of this group. Mohamed was born in Magburaka town about thirty-two years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have three children and one foster child together. One of his children is currently in class six, one in class four, and the others are still not of school age. Mohamed sells medicines. He hawks the medicines in and around Magburaka town. He has been in this business for over seven years now. With this loan, he will be able to add more drugs into his business.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Malap Group

texts.en:
This is Adama K., Sallay K., Fatmata K., Rugiatu K. and Sallay K. . They named their group Malap. These entrepreneurs have gained access to several loans from SMT/Kiva.  Previous loans have had meaningful impacts into the lives of these entrepreneurs. The last loan they received from Kiva through SMT was for Le 1,000,000.00 each. Having successfully repaid that loan, they are now requesting a new loan of Le 1,200,000.00 for each to enable them further strengthen their businesses.

Adama K. (in the middle) is the leader of this group. Adama is thirty-three years of age. She was born in a village called M’Boleh, about four miles from Makeni City, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a carpenter and they have six children who are attending schools. Adama sells market food -- rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), vegetable oil. She also sells cigarettes, soft and hard drinks and clothes.  With this loan, she will expand her business by buying more items to add to her current stock of goods. Adama has been in this business for more than twelve years now.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Rahab

texts.en: Rahab N. is a 37-year-old widow and the mother of three schooling children who are 13, 11 and 9 respectively. She has been in her retail shop business for the last six years and her business is located in Ndabibi area, Naivasha town. Rahab does not have a previous credit history from another micro-finance institution. She got to know about KADET through various marketing and promotion activities done by KADET in Ndabibi area, Naivasha town. Rahab will now be servicing her third loan from KADET. Rahab will use this loan to restock and expand her retail shop. Her future aspiration is to open a supermarket in Ndabibi area, Naivasha town. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To restock and expand her retail shop

loans.name: Believe U Sef Group

texts.en:
Here are Zainab K., Hassanatu K. and Fatmata K.. These local entrepreneurs of Waterloo small town named their group Believe U Sef, a Krio phrase for “Believe in Yourself”. This will be the first loan they are accessing from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses both in terms of size and quality. This will enable them make more sales, improve profit and consequently improving on their standard of living.

Zainab K. (middle) is the leader of this group. Zainab is approximately age twenty-four. She is married to a businessman and they have two children who are still not of school going age. Zainab has been a businesswoman for seven years now. Zainab owns a small stall where she sells cigarettes, biscuits, rice, “margi” (used to give sauce a sweet taste), sugar etc.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Lovina

texts.en:
Lovina is 35 years old and married with seven children. She sells drinks and cooked food. She is from Okada in Edo State.

Lovina is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina sells foodstuffs in retail to her customers. She has been in this business for long. She hopes for the loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is 48 years old and married with 2 children. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: For Better Group

texts.en:
This is Ngadie K., Sallamatu B. and Adama J.. They called their group For Better (a Krio phrase meaning “for prosperity”). They are petty-traders in Waterloo small town, twenty miles from Freetown. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. They are requesting a loan of Le 1,400,000. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses both in terms of size and quality. Consequently they can make better profits and improve on their standards of living.

Ngadie (middle) is the leader of this group. She is thirty-eight years of age and was born in Bo City, in southern Sierra Leone. She is married to a driver and they have four children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Ngadie’s primary business is charcoal but she also sometimes sells foofoo (a delicious ball of paste made from ground cassava).

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Road To Success Group

texts.en:
Osman K. and Mohamed K. are small scale businessmen in Makeni city. They sell used clothes and have been in this business for more than 20 years now. Business had been growing at a very slow pace for these entrepreneurs, but thanks to SMT/Kiva loans, they are now experiencing vast improvements in both their business and personal lives. Previously, each one of them received a loan of Le 800,000.00. Having repaid those fully, they are now each asking for a new loan of Le 1,000,000 to further strengthen their businesses.

Osman K., shown on the left in the photo, is the leader of this group. Born in the village of Ruchain Malal in the Tokolili district of northern Sierra Leone, he is 45, married, and the father of five children. With this loan, Osman will be able to buy at most two bales of used clothes.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth Wacuka is a 41 year old lady married to Samson Ngaruiya, together they have three children who are all going to school. She has been doing small scale farming on her peice of land in the outskirts of Naivasha town for the last five years.

She got to know about KADET through various marketing and promotion activities done by KADET in Naivasha town. This is Elizabeth’s second loan from KADET and Elizabeth will use this loan to plough, buy seeds and prepare the land for the coming planting season.

Her future aspiration is to become a large scale farmer by buying a bigger piece of land and setting up a chain of green groceries shops where she can sell her farm produce to the entire Naivasha town. This will ensure her food security and stable income base.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Ploughing, buying seeds and preparing the land for the coming planting season

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is 40 years old and she is married with 4 children. she sells provisions in retail to her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 34 years old and is married to Jonathan who is a businessman. The couple has two children, Pauline and Victor, who are nine and five years old respectively.

Agnes has been running a nursery school for young children for two years. Agnes' business is located in a densely populated area with mid-level residents who are her clients.

She was introduced to KADET by existing group members and she does not have any previous credit history. She has applied for a loan to progress her business by adding more textbooks to her school and using the balance from this to repair rental houses that she manages on the side. She plans to use the extra profits to expand the classes to higher levels of learning.

Agnes believes she is naturally motivated and focused and her future aspiration is to own a secondary school.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Purchasing textbooks and repairing rental rooms

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis K. is a 55 years old man who is married to Mary Waithera. Together they have three children (two boys and one girl) who all go to school. 

Francis has been operating a retail shop selling different things for the last nine years within Naivasha town. He got to know about KADET through a marketing and promotion activity that was done by KADET staff in the town.

Francis been able to service two loans without any default and he will now be appliying for his third round. Francis will use this loan to expand his shop and boost his stock.

His future aspiration is to have a wholesale shop, buy a plot and build rental houses to boost his income.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Expanding and boosting his stock

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris is 32 years old and married with 4 children. She sells sarongs of various colours. She hopes for the loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Siminatu

texts.en: Siminatu sells breads along Uselu Lagos Road, Benin City.  She is 45 years old and married with 5 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N50000 to purchase more breads and provisions to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more breads

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 35 years old and married with a child. She is a tailor and she has been in business for the past 20 years. She lives in Edo State, Nigeria. Rose hopes for the loan amount of N50000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She say thanks you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Caroline Njeri

texts.en:
Caroline is a 30 year old single lady who is very focused, determined and hardworking.

Caroline has been operating a grocery store for six years. Her business is in a densely populated area near a bus stop and a residential estate. He clients include the tenants in the residentaial area and passerby's from the bus stop.

The client was introduced to KADET by other members of the group whom she meets to fellowship. She has applied for a loan to upgrade her business and with the extra profits she intends to start another similar business in another identified location.

Her future hopes and dreams are to be a wholesale supplier of vegetables to other retailers.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Restocking her grocery store

loans.name: Rutchel

texts.en:
Rutchell V. is a 45-year-old married woman with 4 school-age children who lives in the village of Brgy. Palaka Norte, in the town of Pulupandan, Negros Occidental. She's reaching for her dreams through hard work, patience, self-discipline, and the determination to move away from poverty. As a young girl, she dreamed of having her own business someday.

Rutchell grew up going from town to town with her parents selling dried fish during the town market day. She learned how to deal with customers, how to sell, and how to handle money from her parents. When she got married, she decided to put up her own dried fish vending business. With the help of her husband and a little capital, they started selling dried fish in their community.

Needing more capital to expand her business moved Rutchel to join NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997. With more capital available, she was able to start going to different towns during their market day, exponentially increasing her income. After her 3rd cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rutchell decided to further supplement her family's income potential by opening a general store as an additional source of income. Over the next 10 years, her business provided well for her young family, and she now earns on an average PHP 16,400 per month, which is used to pay for the education of her 4 children, cover the family's household expenses, and set aside some savings for the future of her children.

Rutchell has been an NWTF-Project Dungganon member in good standing for the last 12 years and her last loan of PHP 29,500 was paid in full with no delays in weekly installments. For this 17th loan, Rutchell is again borrowing PHP 29,500 which she intends to use as revolving working capital for her dried fish business and the general store. The profits from this loan will continue to fund the education of her children and provide for the family's household expenses.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: As additional capital for dried fish vending and general store

loans.name: Success Group

texts.en:
'Success' is a group of 5 borrowers led by Emmanuel S., 31 years old, a high school graduate, married with 3 children aged 3 months-3 years; the older ones are still in nursery (academically). Emmanuel also cares for 2 brothers. He lives and sells on Lynch Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia. This community was destroyed by the civil war, so people live in old and burnt houses.

 Emmanuel’s business is brick making. He molds bricks and sells them retail to those that are into renovation, since Lynch street was destroyed by the civil war. 

After making bricks during the daytime, Emmanuel’s night business is operating his little tea shop. He also serves as a photographer to the residents of Lynch Street. Emmanuel started as a brick contractor and raised some money which he used to start up his own business and he has been working at this business for 9 years. He always has goods on hand and sells at an affordable price, so him has a lot of customers.

Emmanuel’s main difficulty is during the rainy season when the rain damages his bricks because he does not have a shelter. Emmanuel needs this loan to purchase more cement in order to produce more bricks that can serve his customers and also to build a shelter to work under and that can also protect his bricks. He hopes to have a big business, if possible a company in the future.

Emmanuel dreams of having access to funds that can help other people through his business.

loans.use: to purchase more cement to produce more bricks and also build a shelter

loans.name: Amen

texts.en: Amen is 42 years old and married with 3 children. She sells provisions and drinks. She hopes for the loan amount of N50000 to purchase more provisions and drinks. She thanks you all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 45 year old and married with 3 children. She owns restaurant where she sells drinks and cooked foods. She had been in the business for sometime now. She is requesting for the loan amount of N50000 to purchase refrigerator and drinks. She says thanks you for the support.

loans.use: To purchase refrigerator and drinks.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 37 years old and single without children. She sells clothes of various sorts and sizes. She hopes for the loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel is 32 years old and married with 3 children. She sells drinks, provisons and foodstuffs. She is from Okada in Edo State, Nigeria. She is requesting for the loan amount of N50000 to purchase a refrigerator for cooling her drinks. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase refrigerator and drinks

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 39 years old and she is married with a child. She sells provisions like milk, sugar, soap, etc. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Emmanuel Ifeanyi

texts.en: Emmanuel Ifeanyi owns a phone booth where he make phone call for people. He also sells phone accessories and phone rechargeable cards. He is 29 years old and single. He is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more phone accessories and phone rechargeable cards. He says thanks you the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more phone  accessories and phone rechargeable cards

texts.en: Gladys sells provisions retail to her customers in Sapele, Delta State, Nigeria. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She is 40 years old and married with 6 children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Beauty is 38 years old and she is married with 4 children. She sells second-hand clothes to her customers and she has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more second-hand clothes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Abemu

texts.en: Abemu is 48 years old and she is married with 2 children. She sells provisions like milk, detergent, toothpapste, etc in her grocery store. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen has been a fashion designer who also sells cloth and drinks for 13 years. Forty-one and married with four children, she lives with her family in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Helen is requesting a loan of N150000 to purchase more cloths and drinks to sell. She thanks you for your help.

loans.use: To purchase more cloths and drinksto sell

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is 32 years old and she is married with 4 children. She sells kerosine in wholesale and retail to her customers.She hopes for the loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more kerosine to sell.She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosine to sell

loans.name: Helene

texts.en:
Helene U. is 45 years old and is married with four children aged between 14 and 5. She lives in the Gasabo district of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, where she has sold spare parts since 2003.
 
Helene operates her business everyday from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Before this loan, her business could not earn her enough profits and she was not able to afford health care for her children, to get more food, or to pay their school fees. With this new loan she hopes to get extra profits which will help her to change the life of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more spare parts

loans.name: Saturday

texts.en: Saturday is a carpenter who also builds roofs for his customers. He is 37 years old and married with four children. He hopes for the loan amount of N40000 to purchase carpentry material. Saturday thanks you for your help.

loans.use: To purchase more carpentry material.

loans.name: Erasinus

texts.en: Erasinus, a 39-year-old married father of two children, sells VCDs in retail and wholesale to his customers.  He hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more VCDs to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Josiane Clarisse

texts.fr: A. Josiane Clarisse est mariée à MITCHOZOUNOU Jean. Josiane Clarisse est mère de quatre  enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Josiane Clarisse vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille.  C’est des sacs de charbon de bois que Josiane Clarisse vend chez elle à domicile. Josiane Clarisse achète ses produits à Dantokpa, grand marché International du Bénin. Josiane Clarisse est une cliente d’ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Josiane Clarisse a besoin de plus de moyens financiers qu’elle n’en possède pour augmenter la quantité de son stock de charbon de bois. C’est la raison pour laquelle Josiane Clarisse demande de crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement. 1380

loans.use: Achat de sacs de charbons de bois.

loans.name: Boskelavi Groups 4, 6

texts.en:
The “Boske La Vi” or “Search for Life” group 2 is excited to be receiving their 2nd loan. The group has a variety of businesses from a butcher and seller of live animals to charcoal making and bamboo sales. Nejean R. is a representative of the group. He is a 40yr old husband and father to 6 children.
Nejean is a longterm charcoal maker and seller. He also grows and sells bamboo in the local market. He is grateful for what the first loan was able to do not only for his family but also for his community. He says “ there were people who wanted to do business, but needed a little bit of help…Esperanza is helping.” He dreams of being able to grow his business and send his kids to school with greater ease. On behalf of Nejean, Boske La Vi, and Esperanza we thank you for your support.

loans.use: tranportation bags, tools, wood

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi, 32 years old and married with four children, sells carpets and rug. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more carpets to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more carpets to sell

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice, 55 years old and married with six children, sells tomatoes and peppers in retail to her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more tomatoes and peppers to sell.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tomatoes and peppers to sell

loans.name: Xiomara Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Xiomara A. P., tiene 49 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos ya mayores de edad. La señora Xiomara se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general como vestuario, zapatos, artículos de belleza, etc. Cabe señalarse, que hace más de ocho años  que se dedicarse a este negocio. El cual dio inicio vendiendo joyas y bolsos de mujer, Poco a poco fue realizando un mayor inventario hasta llegar al que tiene ahora ella siempre ha hecho muchos esfuerzos para sacar adelante a sus hijos. El crédito será invertido en la compra de mercancías para aprovechar el incremento de las ventas en los meses venideros. Su sueño es llegar a tener una tienda boutique de buen prestigio ubicada en el mercado, que brinde mayores ingresos y estabilidad a su familia.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Etienne

texts.en:
Etienne K. is 48 years old and is married with five children aged between 20 and 11. He lives in the Gasabo District of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Etienne owns a small shop where he has sold different kinds of products such as sugar, salt, rice, juice and soap since 2001. He operates his business everyday from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.

Before this loan he is requesting from Vision Finance Company, his business could not give him enough profit and he was not able to afford health care for his children or pay their school fees. With this new loan he hopes to generate extra profits which will help him to change the life of his family. It will also help him to expand the business so that he earns more profits in future.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday sells drinks and foods in a restaurant, his wife help in him. He use his bus for commercials purpose. Sunday is 49 years old and married with 5 children. He hopes for the loan amount of N60000 to purchase more food stuffs for his business. He says thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuff

loans.name: Nosa

texts.en: Nosa, a 39-year-old married hair stylist, lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She hopes for the loan amount of N50000 to purchase more hair extensions, hair cream and clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and hair extension

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita sells planks in wholesale and retail to her customers in Sapele, Delta state, Nigeria. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more planks to sell.  Rita, who is 33 years old and married with four children, says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate has sold provisions, palm oil and drinks for a number of years. Thirty years old and married with four children, she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Kate is requesting the loan amount of N100000 to purchase more provisions, palm oil and drinks to sell. She thanks you for the loan support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, palm oil and drinks to sell

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana sells provisions. She is married with six children and she is 50 years old. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret sells sarongs and clothes. She has been in the business for years. She is 49 year old and married with four children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is requesting a loan of 60,000 nairas to purchase more sarongs and clothes to sell. She says thanks you for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase sarongs and clothes to sell

loans.name: Nwokocha

texts.en: Nwokocha is married with 5 children and she is 45 years old. She lives in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria. She sells kitchen utensils like cooking pots. She has been in this business for long. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 to purchase more kitchen utensils to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kitchen utensils

loans.name: United Group

texts.en:
Willametta T. purchases rice, flour, eggs, oil, etc. wholesale and sells retail to the residents of Benson Street. She has been running this business for more than 15 years. She caters to her children’s needs from this business. Willametta started with a little money from her mother who worked for the city police. She stopped giving credit to customers, because it nearly bankrupted her. Willametta organises her business; she plans her daily expenses and remains consistent. She sells at reasonable prices which is what really makes her business progress without bankruptcy.

Willametta is 32 years old, a single mother with four children between the ages of 3 and 9 years and in nursery school to 11th grade. Willametta was forced to leave school when she was in the 9th grade, because she got pregnant and was abandoned by the child’s father. She had no choice but to leave school to fend for herself and the child. After this, she met the fellow who fathered the rest of her children, but he died later. Willamette lives on Benson Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Willametta needs this loan to purchase more rice, oil, flour, eggs, etc. in order to earn more profit so that she can expand to owning a shop. Willametta dreams of giving her children a better life and meeting their needs. 

United Group is a group of five borrowers led by Willametta T..

loans.use: To purchase more rice, oil, flour, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Dora Isabel

texts.es: Dora Isabel A. Vélez tiene 58 años. Su actividad económica es una pulpería. Ella es una persona muy alegre y disfruta ya que es una mujer muy trabajadora. Dora inicio este negocio por cuenta propia y con mucho esfuerzo pues para ella lo importante es mantener a sus 2 hijos que están a su cargo y ofrecerles la oportunidad de estudio. Ella no logro terminar sus estudios por lo que actualmente tuvo muchas dificultades es por eso que ahora no quiere que sus hijos tengan las mismas dificultades, a pesar de poseer muy poca educación es una persona con muchas ganas de salir adelante. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de granos básicos, golosinas, refrescos naturales, pan y jugos. Su deseo es comprar su propia casa.
texts.en:
Dora Isabel A. Vélez is 58 years old. Her economic endeavor is a small store. She is a happy, cheerful person and very hard working woman. Dora started this business on her own and with great effort because for her the most important thing is to support her 2 children and offer them the opportunity to study. She was not able to finish her studies and as a result had many difficulties. That is why she doesn’t want her children to have the same difficulties. Despite having very little education, she is a person with a great desire to succeed. The loan she requests is for working capital in order to buy basic grains, sweets, natural drinks, bread and juices. Her wish is to buy a home of her own.

Translated from Spanish by Joseph Tobin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Concepcion Del Rosario

texts.es: Concepción del Rosario M. V. con la edad de 36 años, tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación León 2000. Ella tiene 4 hijos a su cargo que actualmente están estudiando gracias al gran sacrificio de Concepción. La actividad económica a la que se dedica es una pulpería. Hace más de 4 años que humildemente se gana de esta manera el pan de cada día. Por lo que sus inicios se dan porque su esposo le ayudo a establecer este negocio con muy pocos recursos ya que tenían que proporcionarles a sus hijos la oportunidad de estudiar y alimento diario, por lo que con el apoyo de ambos logran salir adelante. El financiamiento que actualmente solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de golosinas, refrescos naturales, pan, galletas, granos básicos. Su deseo es que su familia permanezca unida para seguir trabajando.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Sonia Margarita

texts.es: Actualmente tiene 26 años, es casada y con 2 hijos. Aún son pequeños, su esposo confecciona playeras y los dos cubren los gastos de la casa. Tiene una tienda de consumo diario, pero la mayor venta es de aguas gaseosas ya que ella distribuye en el sector de su casa. El préstamo que necesita es para seguir creciendo en su negocio, ampliar su tienda y comprar más gaseosas y así tener surtido. Sus metas siempre serían agrandar el negocio y salir adelante con el, teniendo más clientes y no quedarles mal por no tener lo que ellos necesitan.
texts.en:
She is 26, married, and has two small children. Her husband makes t-shirts, and they both cover the household expenses. She has a convenience store. Carbonated water is what she sells the most. She distributes in the area of her house. The loan that she needs is to keep growing in her business, to expand her store, and to buy more soft drinks in order to have them in stock. Her goals are always to make her store bigger and to get ahead with it, to have more customers, and not to be in their disfavor by not having what they need.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock the store

loans.name: Louange Limonade Group

texts.en:
The “Louange Limonade” or “Praise of Limonade” Group is a made of twenty male and female entrepreneurs. They are all excited about expanding their current businesses with the reception of their firS. loan. The group has a variety of businesses from cosmetics to clothes and from seasonal items such as notebooks to ice in both large and small amounts. Nelcia G.  is one of four representatives of the group. She is a 36yr old wife and mother to three children.
Nelcia is very in touch with her community and accordingly varies her merchandise with seasons. She has a few staple products that she knows her clients always need, including sugar, flour, rice and oil. With the opening of school she said she will stock up on notebooks and other supplies for children going to school. She hopes to be able to grow her business and create more financial security for her family. On behalf of Nelcia, Louange, and Esperanza we thank you for your support.

loans.use: notebooks, pens, pencils, sugar, oil, rice, flour

loans.name: Ernesto Jose

texts.es: El señor Ernesto José A. posee un negocio que es una tapicería, el tiene 47 año de edad. Su negocio está ubicado en su casa de habitación. Hace más de 18 años que se dedica a este negocio con mucho sacrificio. El es padre de tres hijos de los cuales 2 asisten al colegio y el tercero que es menor de edad. el señor Ernesto además de trabajar en su casa, realiza algunos trabajos en Managua en una cooperativa de buses, en  donde brinda mantenimiento al mobiliario de las unidades, compra la materia prima de su negocio en el mercado de Managua en donde los precios son más favorables y así el señor puede ganar un poco mas de dinero. A pesar de no tener mucho dinero vive muy feliz con su familia y cuenta con todos los servicios básicos. Como toda persona luchadora tiene los sueños de continuar trabajando para su familia.
texts.en:
Sr. Ernesto José A. is 47 years old and the father of 3 children, of whom two attend college while the third child is still a minor.

For the past 18 years, he has been dedicated to the upholstery business that he has managed with great sacrifice. He operates his business out of his home. In addition, he performs some work for a bus cooperative in Managua in which he provides reupholstery and maintenance services for their vehicles. He buys all of his materials for his primary business in Managua because the prices are more favorable and enable him to earn more income.

Despite not having much money, Sr. Ernesto lives happily with his family and has all the basic services. He possesses a fighting spirit and continues to work to fulfill his family’s dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to purchase materials

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose, a 40-year-old married mother of four children, sells herbs and local pots. She has been in this business for several years and hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 to purchase more herbs to sell. Rose says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more herbs to sell

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience sells eggs in dozen and she also sells bags. She has been in this business for long. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 to purchase more eggs to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more eggs to sell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice owns a restaurant where she sells cooked foods and drinks. Sixty years old and married with six children, she has been in the business for many years. Alice, who lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria, is requesting the loan amount of N100000 to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell. She thanks you for the loan support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Cumbe (Ceunca) Group

texts.es:
